Metadata: Endocrine control of cartilage growth in coho salmon: GH influence "in vivo" on the response to IGF-I "in vitro"

The purpose of this study is to examine further the effect of growth hormone (GH) on cartilage growth and its potential interaction with IGF-I. Ceratobranchial cartilages from coho salmon ("Oncorhynchus kisutch") parr, injected with growth hormone at 4mug/g body weight or with saline, were sampled monthly from February to July. "In vivo" GH action and "in vitro" IGF-I action on ceratobranchial cartilage in coho salmon were judged by determining thymidine and sulfate incorporation. Experiments were done repeatedly during the period of parr-smolt transformation to detect possible developmental or seasonal changes in response to GH "in vivo" and to IGF-I "in vitro".
